sourceDesc.p: Initially created on Tuesday 26th March 2013 by the form at http://www.tei-c.org.uk/Roma/.

projectDesc.p: LAUDATIO: Long-term Access and Usage of Deeply Annotated Information. The management and archiving of digital research data is an overlapping field for linguistics, library and information science (LIS) and computer science. These disciplines are cooperating in the LAUDATIO project. The name LAUDATIO is an abbreviation for Long-term Access and Usage of Deeply Annotated Information. The project is funded by the German Research Foundation from 2011-2014. The departments of Corpus Linguistics as well as Historical Linguistics, and the Computer and Media Service (CMS) at Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin and The National Institute for Research in Computer Science and Control (INRIA France) are project partners cooperating with the Berlin School of Library and Information Science (BSLIS).

revisionDesc.change: Addition of attribute role value "transcription" for author.
Addtion of values for @ident of elementSpec for the annotations in the document. Changing the version number system: change from 0.2 to full counts.
Additions repsecting the documentation part of the ODD.

div.head: Application and project
div.p: What should you know about a corpus before (re-)using it?

The LAUDATIO-Repository provides open access to historical corpora. To find corpora for your own research and to (re-)use them you need metadata concerning for example
the corpus title,
version,
documents in the corpus,
formats,
annotations,
checking methods
and the responsible editors, annotators and projects. The TEI customization provides a metadata schema for the LAUDATIO-Repository which enables a structured and uniform display of the corpus metadata and facetted and free-text search for all corpora.
The ODD is based on several concepts and models developed by the LAUDATIO-Project in cooperation with the SFB 632 D1 with ANNIS and SaltNPepper.

div.head: Basic concepts
div.p: For each corpus in the repository the metadata are stored in TEI XML. There are three ODDs which contain the metadata for a corpus, the documents of the corpus and the annotation in the documents. This customization refers to the corpus-linguistic meta model of a corpus and its components, see figure 1 below.

The meta model refers to all kinds of historical corpora independent of their research purpose, size, primary sources and preparation. It covers all kinds of annotation such as token annotation, dependenciy annotation and tree annotation. For the model each of the annotations consist at least an attribute and a value.

figure.head: Corpus concept
figure.figDesc: The figure represents a model of the corpus.

div.p: The model assumes that there are three concepts: 'corpus', 'document' and 'annotation': A corpus contains one or more documents. Two or more corpora built a super corpus. 'Documents' are primary texts which are digitized and annotated in some way. Such a text may be a whole publication such as novels and articles or extracts put of them. The concept 'document' contains a set of annotations. Annotations are linguistic information of every kind which are assigned either to every token (token annotation), to more than one token at the time (e.g. span annotation) or to within a certain relation such as dependence or hierarchy relations. Each type of annotation can be modeled as key-value-pair. Hence, annotations constitute documents, documents constitute corpora, corpora constitute super corpora.

For further information and examples see Odebrecht, Carolin (2014) Modeling Linguistic Research Data for a Repository for Historical Corpora. Digital Humanities 2014 Conference. 8.7.-12.7.2014, Lausanne. Odebrecht, Carolin, Krause, Thomas (2013) Metadata in an Infrastructure for Historical Corpora. SFB 732 Incremental Specification in Context. Kolloquium.Stuttgart 20.06.2013. Odebrecht, Carolin (2013) Modellierung von linguistischen Forschungsdaten. Korpuslinguisitk Kolloquium 13.11.2013, Berlin.

div.head: Technical realization of the meta model
div.p: The LAUDATIO customization creates TEI schema for the LAUDATIO metadata concepts 'Corpus', 'Document' and 'PreparationStep' by mapping the meta model and TEI p5 header structure. The meta model is realized with TEI p5 by using one TEI header for each concept:
Each concept contains fileDesc, encodingDesc and revisionDesc. The concepts 'Corpus' and 'Document' contain profileDesc because they refer to language used in the data.

The header have relations to each other in the following way: The 'Corpus Header' provides lists of documents corresponding to the 'Document Header' and list of annotation corresponding to the 'PreparationStep Header'. Each 'Document Header' contains a list of annotations for each document in the corpus corresponding to the 'PreparationStep Header'.

div.head: TEI p5 customization for the concept 'Document'
div.p: The ODD combines the modules core, header, textstructure, tagdocs, namesdates and msdescription but removes most of the available elements and changes several attribute classes, e.g. add a TEI attribute to an element. Thus, the customization is very restricted and allows little variation in selecting elements and attributes.

div.head: Core structure
div.p: The core module is very restricted and only contains the elements corresponding to bibliographic metadata such as author, editor, date and title and more general structural element such as list, item, label, p and ref.

No class or general module modification were made. The TEI schema is only locally restricted. That means that no inheritance relations or module relations were changed, deleted or added. The customization is documented in the section 'Formal declaration'.
All encoded metadata refer to information addressing each document, e.g. the editors and authors of the document, the revision history and the available annotations.

div.head: Basic TEI header structure
div.p: LAUDATIO metadata schema for the concept 'Document' contains much more elements and modules comparing to standard TEI header which are usually used for the purpose of text encoding only. For validity, fileDesc, the profileDesc, encodingDesc and revisionDesc are required.

The fileDesc contains the following elements where the basic meaning are left untouched but are referred to the concept 'Document', meaning the element author refers to the author of the document, the element title refers to the title of a single document. Important elements used within teiHeader are:

The titleStmt contains the title, editors and authors of the document with the declaration pf forname and surname.
...
... ...
... ...

The publicationStmt refers to a printed publication either an edition or the first publication
... ... ... ... ...

Publication may be published within series. seriesStmt provides information about the publication series of publication of the document.
... ... ...

Additionally to publicationStmt and seriesStmt which cover either the editorial publication history or the first publication of the primary texts msDesc gives further information about the manuscript if necessary.
...
... ... ...
... ... ... ... ...
...
msDesc shall only give a short overview over the publication history of each document of the corpus in order to use the view and search functions of the LAUDATIO-Repository. Thus, recordHist is used to provide repertory references where much more detailed information about the manuscript history is given.

The profileDesc only contains metadata concerning the language of the every single document.
... ... ...

The encodingDesc contains a list of annotation keys sorted by rough linguistic categories:
The ident of elementSpec contains a fixed list of categories as a rough division of annotations according to their functions: Transcription, Lexical, Syntactical, Morphological, Graphical, MarkUp, Meta and Other.

revisionDesc refers to the version history of the whole corpus. Corpora in the LAUDATIO-Repository may have several versions. The changes between these versions will be provided here with focus on the document.
... ...

moduleRef.include: author biblScope editor date p pubPlace publisher ref schemaSpec title
change encodingDesc extent fileDesc idno langUsage language profileDesc publicationStmt revisionDesc seriesStmt sourceDesc teiHeader titleStmt

attDef.gloss: You must specify the exact reference to LAUDATIO metadata module schema 'Corpus'.

valItem.gloss: The title only refers to the LAUDATIO metadata module 'Corpus'

attDef.gloss: You must indicate what type of extent you refere of

valItem.gloss: The size of the corpus is given in token.
The size of the corpus is given in words.

attDef.gloss: You must identify the module of the LAUDATIO metada schema, e.g. CorpusHeader, DocumentHeader, PreparationHeader

moduleRef.except: accMat acquisition additional additions adminInfo binding bindingDesc catchwords collation colophon condition custEvent custodialHist decoDesc decoNote depth dim dimensions explicit filiation finalRubric foliation handDesc height heraldry incipit institution layout layoutDesc material msContents msItem msItemStruct msPart musicNotation objectDesc physDesc provenance rubric scriptDesc seal sealDesc secFol signatures stamp summary support supportDesc surrogates typeDesc watermark width

div.head: Contact
div.p: Carolin Odebrecht, Korpuslinguistik und Morphologie. Institut für deutsche Sprache und Linguistik, Humboldt-universität zu Berlin. carolin.odebrecht@hu-berlin.de

LAUDATIO: Long-term Access and Usage of Deeply Annotated Information. The management and archiving of digital research data is an overlapping field for linguistics, library and information science (LIS) and computer science. These disciplines are cooperating in the LAUDATIO project. The name LAUDATIO is an abbreviation for Long-term Access and Usage of Deeply Annotated Information. The project is funded by the German Research Foundation from 2011-2014. The departments of Corpus Linguistics as well as Historical Linguistics, and the Computer and Media Service (CMS) at Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin and The National Institute for Research in Computer Science and Control (INRIA France) are project partners cooperating with the Berlin School of Library and Information Science (BSLIS).
